subject: Re: [GAMESNETWORK] CFP: The Aesthetics of Computer Games
body:
I think if we REALLY
        want to make a statement, then we need to only hold conferences
        in places that do NOT have problematic discriminatory laws.
        Instead, we need to hold them as close as possible to those
        places, and then raise funds to help make it possible for
        students and other precarious faculty from those nearby
        countries to attend.


Holding a conference in
        a place that officially outlaws LGBTQ people also means that the
        papers submitted to the conference must be censored, because any
        kind of unbiased research related to LGBTQ issues is also likely
        to be dangerous. That's NOT what scholarship is supposed to be
        about.

On 6/7/2019 1:23 PM, Carl Therrien
      wrote:






Dear Michael,
        




I'm just trying to think of solutions that would make
          participants feel safe to submit. People on location know best
          if they could be held accountable for the presentations made
          by participants outside the country. It might seem a bit
          paranoid to think the government would go to the extent of
          intercepting and listening if it is not presented as LGBT
          related, but in such a context it would not be surprising that
          authorities pay close attention to any event in academia and
          be very proactive about holding people accountable. I trust
          orgnizers know best about this.



          Again, no easy solutions. It is hard to balance the benefits
          for the local communities of having these conferences be
          hosted in parts of the world with violent regimes and the need
          to be as inclusive as possible for every instalment of the
          conference.



          Best,
